abstract.p: Letter by Elizabeth C Gorski responds to May 25 article on cyberspace news; says article failed to mention the decades-long interactive feature of print newspapers: crossword puzzle

block.p: As a crossword puzzle maker (including some for the daily and Sunday New York Times), I'd like to point out that the May 25 article about online newspapers did not mention a decades-long interactive feature of print newspapers: the crossword puzzle. No other part of the newspaper invites the reader to interact with the page.

Though I'm able to download The New York Times puzzle and solve it offline, I wouldn't dream of it. Each morning I buy the newspaper and turn to the puzzle page. I need that tactile interaction with the printed page to get my brain going. I have a high-risk tolerance, so I use ink. The handwritten letters indicate whether my solving journey was smooth (neat, with no cross-outs) or awful (in which the case the grid is gooped-up enough to be re-used as a Rorschach test). The computer screen leaves no such evidence. It's too clinical for real puzzle solving.

ELIZABETH C. GORSKI New York City
